title: "Do it yourself..." custom JavaFX 2.x controls
summary: Every frontend developer knows the problem, the project you are working on requires a control that is not part of the standard library which raises the question...“How to do a custom control myself ?“ This talk will show you one way you could choose to create those custom controls in JavaFX. The internal structure of a JavaFX control with it‘s different parts like control, skin, behavior and css file will be explained. In addition the differences between a Java Swing component and a JavaFX control will be shown to give the audience with a Swing background an idea on how to convert existing Java Swing components to JavaFX controls. In addition it will be shown how one could get an existing design converted into a control. Therefore a small control will be created in a drawing program and afterwards be converted into code using different approaches like SVG to FXML, FXG to FXML and FXG to Java code.

type.name: Conference
type.description:

author.speakerBio:
Gerrit Grunwald is working as a software engineer at Canoo Engineering AG (Basel, Switzerland). He is responsible for visualizations of all kinds. His technical interests include Java desktop software development and specifically the subareas - JavaFX, Java Swing and HTML5 controls.
He‘s a decent frequent blogger, founder and leader of the Java User Group in Münster (Germany), where he‘s also living.
He has been involved in the IT industry since 1996, when he started studying Applied Physics at the University of Applied Sciences Münster (Germany).
author.name: Gerrit Grunwald

user.speakerBio: Freelance since 1997, I am doing everything between developer and information systems architect, having my main emphasis on Java Enterprise Edition 6 technologies. Occasionally, I speak at conferences. I’m founder of the Brussels Java User Group (http://brujug.be) and co-founder of the Random Hacks of Kindness Belgium (http://rhok.be). I’m currently also member of the DEVOXX and DEVOXX4Kids team. Despite of my passion for Java, I still am very connected to more industrial ICT, electronics and low-level programming (Embedded Technologies, Ardiuno, Member of the NAO development program, Lego Mindstorm, C/C++ and much more).  You can find me on twitter @Imifos or on my blog http://www.lucubratory.eu/

David Delabassee is a Product Manager working at Oracle in the GlassFish and Java EE Team. Prior to that, he spent the last 10 years at Sun Microsystems focusing on Java end-to-end (from the smart card to the high end server), all the related technologies, and the developer tools. He has been involved in Java projects since the early days of this technology. David is a steering member of Devoxx, Europe largest Java conference. 
In his spare time, he enjoy tinkering and playing with technologies such as Java, Arduino, Processing, Linux, etc.

Stephan Janssen is a serial entrepreneur that has founded several successful organizations such as the Belgian Java User Group (BeJUG) in 1996, JCS Int. in 1998, JavaPolis (now Devoxx) in 2001 and recently Parleys.com in 2006.

He has been using Java since its early releases in 1995 with experience of developing and implementing real world Java solutions in the finance and manufacturing industries.

He was selected by BEA Systems as the first European (independent) BEA Technical Director.

He has also been recognized by the Server Side as one of the 54 Who is Who in Enterprise Java 2004.

Sun has recognized in 2005 his efforts for the Java Community and has engaged Stephan in the Java Champion project.

He has spoken at numerous Java and JUG conferences around the world.

user.speakerBio: Stephen Chin is a Java Technology Ambassador at Oracle specializing in UI technology and co-author of the Pro JavaFX Platform 2 title, which is the leading technical reference for JavaFX. He has been featured at Java conferences around the world including Devoxx, Codemash, OSCON, J-Fall, GeeCON, Jazoon, and JavaOne, where he twice received a Rock Star Award. In his evenings and weekends, Stephen is an open-source hacker, working on projects including ScalaFX, a DSL for JavaFX in the Scala language, Visage, a UI oriented JVM language, JFXtras, a JavaFX component and extension library, and Apropos, an Agile Project Portfolio scheduling tool written in JavaFX. Stephen can be followed on twitter @steveonjava and reached via his blog: http://steveonjava.com/

Next to his day job as a Java, web and mobile developer for Parleys.com and Devoxx, he is active in the Devoxx steering committee and the Belgium JUG where he drives the coding dojo sessions. Jo spends most of his free time experimenting with new technologies and enjoys speaking about Swing, JavaFX, Flex, Mercurial/GIT and lately HTML5. title: SIMBA: secure your Java Applications fast and easy
summary: SIMBA stands for Security Integration Module for Business Applications and is an User Access Management system that can be integrated with any business application.  The main purpose is to secure your application fast and easy and make security more accessible for developers who are not security experts.  SIMBA has lots of advantages over the standard big security tools: customize your security based on your entry points, easy user management, no configuration nightmare (any developer can do this), distributed deployment, lightweight,... and of course the price.  SIMBA is a Belgian OWASP open-source project.

author.speakingReferences: OWASP Benelux 2012
author.speakerBio: Koen Vanderloock has been a Java developer for 10 years now.  Due to problems with our previous security product I go involved in Application Security about 4 years ago.
author.name: Koen Vanderloock

user.speakerBio:
Gert Leenders is working as a JavaEE Architect at Axi Nv where he started his career in 2001 as a .NET developer specializing in GDI+ Development. After 2 years he traded the .NET platform for Java J2EE development.

More and more convinced of RAD's potential he joined a team at Axi with the goal to develop an RAD Framework/Generator on top of the J2EE platform for faster, more reliable and maintainable web applications (Framework name: Jaxx). In 2005 Roeland Saels and he participated in the JavaPolis RAD Race with the JAXX Framework, which resulted in a shared first place.

title: Start me up ... in the Cloud
summary:
Cloud is such a change that transforms the way we do software development. Enter the Cloud-age, free from middleware, IT and infrastructure worries - just business needs and developers to implement them. 
During this talk, we will discuss the major changes Cloud is introducing to our jobs, as a huge step to even more agility. We will also demonstrate them : we will (try to) create the new Google / FaceBook / Twitter success-story start-up - no guarantee we succeed - with only one developer and the awesome capabilities of a PaaS to free our imagination.

author.speakingReferences:
many French JUGs including ParisJUG, 
AgileTour (rennes, nantes, vannes, paris)
JugSummerCamp, BreizhCamp, RivieraDev, Fossa

Techno-addict and opensource developer, he joined the Apache Maven team in 2007, focussing on Google Web Toolkit plugin, and later the Jenkins community. With many relations in French Java community, he launched in 2008 a Java User Group at Rennes : the BreizhJUG. He also has spoken on conferences about Maven and Software Factory, and actively supports the Java community. He joined CloudBees to contribute an awesome project : run Java in the cloud, from source code to production.

title: continuous delivery in action
summary: Continuous delivery today is not just a buzzword anymore. Using de-facto standard Jenkins CI server, we will demonstrate a build-pipeline in action to deploy an application with complete unit / functional / performance testing, and then push changes to production. We will also focus on some advanced techniques to optimize the pipeline for efficiency
wikiPageName: continuous delivery in action

title: Modularizing a JavaEE application
summary:
Building a modular JavaEE web application presents some strong challenges, especially when working on sizable enterprise applications. The development model is usualy monolithic. This makes it hard to extend the application.

Hear how the ever static war as well as the usual configuration files like faces-config.xml or web.xml are built/generated at runtime using the different jar from the server, thanks to a templating/fragment model.

Developers also use an extension point model that makes possible this level of modularity. Each jar can contain a part of the war, the necessary java code needed for this war, the application server configuration files or the properties files used for internationalization.
Going further in the modularity/agility issue, the developers use a modifed version of tomcat's default class loader which offer hot reloading of their Java code. This also makes the reloading of extension points, fragments and templates possible.

author.speakingReferences: He previously speaked at EclipseCon Europe 2011, OW2con 2011 and NuxeoWold2011.

title: ElasticMQ: what is it, and how does it work? (Or: Scala/JGroups/Netty/Squeryl in practice.)
summary:
ElasticMQ is a message queue server, with optional journaling, replication and an Amazon-SQS compatible interface.

The first part will cover ElasticMQ as a server. I will explain the model of sending and receiving messages used both by SQS and ElasticMQ. Then I will show how to run an embedded server e.g. during tests. There will also be a live replication demo with a cluster of ElasticMQ servers. You will see that no message is lost even when an accidental kill -9 occurs.

Second part will be a case study of the technologies used. ElasticMQ is written in Scala; I will show examples where Scala was especially useful (e.g. the Cake Pattern). The libraries are also interesting: JGroups is a really easy way to implement replication; Squeryl offers type-safe SQL queries; and Netty is the way to build an asynchronous HTTP server. These will be short intros so that you feel encouraged to play at home. 

The project is fully open-source. You are encouraged to fork at: https://github.com/adamw/elasticmq.

author.speakerBio:
I am one of the co-founders of SoftwareMill, a company specialising in delivering customised software solutions (http://softwaremill.com, "Extraordinary software as a standard"), based on Java, Scala and JBoss technologies. I graduated from the University of Warsaw, receiving a Master's Degree in Computer Science. I am also involved in some open-source projects. Firstly as the founder and lead developer of Hibernate Envers, a Hibernate core module, which provides entity versioning/auditing capabilities; Envers is also included in JBoss AS since version 7.0.2. Secondly, as the founder of ElasticMQ, an SQS-compatible messaging server written in Scala.

Moreover I work on several small projects around static analysis (using JSR 308 - Typestate Annotations/ Checkers Framework and FindBugs), and some CDI/Weld (not always portable) extensions, like autofactories or stackable security interceptors. I am also interested in improving the ways we use Dependency Injection, and some simple electronics using Arduino/RaspberryPi/Lego. When not working, I enjoy hiking in the mountains (summer), skiing (winter), playing tennis and since June 2010, spending time with my daughter.

I have been a speaker at numerous conferences, including Devoxx, Jazoon, Confitura, JDD and Herbstcampus, as well as on Warsaw, Poznan and Riviera JUGs.

My blog: http://www.warski.org/blog
author.name: Adam Warski

title: Next Generation Messaging With ActiveMQ Apollo
summary: Learn about new ActiveMQ architecture designed for machines with higher core counts. ActiveMQ Apollo is the new broker core written in Scala using reactor based thread model. Besides the architecture, the talk will cover Stomp messaging protocol and especially new changes introduced in version 1.1 of the protocol. Finally, the focus will be on the current Apollo features and plans for the future development.

summary: This session shows how to create rich web applications using AJAX with Apache Wicket. First David will explain the basic concepts of Behaviors and wicket ajax components. title: Putting the App back into Web Apps : Building the modern web with Dart
summary: Dart is more than a new structured web programming language. Dart's tools, libraries, and editor help developers from all platforms build complex, high performance web apps. This is a practical session, highlighting Dart's implementation of Web Components. Best of all, we'll show you how to run these Dart apps today across the entire modern web with our compiler to JavaScript.

title: 7 Things: How to make good teams great
summary:
Developing a product over years is a tough job. It is hard for the team to stay excited on a day to day basis. So how can you improve motivation and innovation of agile teams and still keep the focus on building a great product?

I want to share with you how we at Atlassian used an agile approach to become one of the most successful developer tool companies in the world. This talk will cover topics like FedEx days, 20-percent time, keeping distraction away from developers, lunchtime talks, dogfooding and much more.

title: Scala Puzzlers
summary:
One of the most advanced programming languages of today has surely outgrown the gotchas, puzzlers and head-scratchers of the past. Really?

Prepare to be surprised, entertained and...well, puzzled! We'll present a selection of seemingly simple examples which demonstrate that there's plenty of head-scratching left in Scala!
Let your mind be challenged by unexpected and unintuitive behaviour and results and learn something about your favourite language in the process. And unlike in a real magic show, we'll even be giving away the solutions :-)

title: Developing portable PaaS applications
summary:
In demonstrating how the Java cloud library jclouds makes it easy to work with cloud services in a simple, portable way, we've written a bunch of applications that run on many of today's Platform as a Service offerings, including Google App Engine, CouldBees RUN@cloud, RedHat OpenShift, Cloud Foundry, Heroku and DotCloud. 

In this session, we'd like to share our experience in developing and, just as importantly, managing portable Java PaaS applications. We'll set the context by identifying some pointers to help you decide whether a public or private PaaS makes sense for your application, or whether an IaaS solution in a public or private cloud might be more appropriate. We'll then compare PaaS APIs, provided resources and replacements, and discuss ways of separating your core portable business logic from your "PaaS binding". 

Finally, we'll look at "live-from-IDE" development, continuous integration and deployment options and touch on monitoring and application management in a multi-PaaS setup.

type.name: University
type.description:
• University talks are in depth presentations of 3 hours 
  • They are recorded for Parleys.com

title: Behaviour Driven Development on the JVM - a State of the Union
summary: Behavior Driven Development (BDD) is an increasingly popular variation on Test Driven Development, which helps developers think more about what they are testing, in terms of "executable specifications" rather than conventional tests. But there are dozens of BDD tools for the JVM out there: how do you know what to use, and when? In this talk, we will look at the various BDD tools available for Java developers, both in Java and in other JVM languages. We will look at the pros and cons of the various tools, and learn which might be best suited for your team. Finally, you will discover the relationship between behavior driven development and automated acceptance testing, and why you probably need both.

author.speakingReferences: Devoxx 2010, JavaOne 2010, JavaOne 2009, Devoxx 2008, etc
author.speakerBio: John is an experienced consultant and trainer specialising in Enterprise Java, Web Development, and Open Source technologies, based in Sydney, Australia. Well known in the Java community for his many published articles, and as author of Java Power Tools, John helps organisations around the world to optimize their Java development processes and infrastructures and provides training and mentoring in open source technologies, SDLC tools, and agile development processes. John is CEO of Wakaleo Consulting, a company that provides consulting, training and mentoring services in Enterprise Java and Agile Development. John is the author of 'Java Power Tools' and of the recently published 'Jenkins: The Definitive Guide'
author.name: John Smart

title: Improve your Java code, functional-style - Now!
summary: Functional programming is all the rage. Functional programming can undoubtably produce cleaner and more expressive code. But why switch to Scala or wait for Java 8? In fact, there are many ways to dramatically improve your code quality using a more functional style today! This talk will discuss how techniques such as functional programming, fluent APIs and other clean coding practices can make your code more concise, more readable, and much easier to maintain. But, more importantly, you will learn about libraries such as LambdaJ and Google Guava that make this possible today, with your existing Java code base!
wikiPageName: Improve your Java code, functional-style - Now!
wikiTitle: Improve your Java code, functional-style - Now!
smallTitle: Improve your Java code, functional-style - Now! by John Smart

title: To ATDD and beyond! Better Automated Acceptance Testing on the JVM
summary:
Test Driven Development is a game changer for developers, but Automated Acceptance Testing (ATDD) is a game changer for the whole team! More than just a testing technique, Automated Acceptance Testing is both a collaboration tool and a vital step on the road to Continuous Delivery.

In this talk, you will see a real-world demo applying practical ATDD techniques to real-world projects using JBehave, Selenium 2 and Thucydides. Learn how to write better and more maintainable automated acceptance tests, and see how a well-designed set of automated acceptance tests can also be a powerful documentation and reporting tool. 

See how tools like JBehave and Thucidides can help you structure your acceptance tests and generate powerful documentation, with narrative feature descriptions, screen shots, test coverage, and project progress reports. 

And learn how product owners use ATDD and Thucydides to drive, coordinate and document releases.
wikiPageName: To ATDD and beyond! Better Automated Acceptance Testing on the JVM
wikiTitle: To ATDD and beyond! Better Automated Acceptance Testing on the JVM
smallTitle: To ATDD and beyond! Better Automated Acceptance Testing on the JVM by John Smart

title: Software project estimation techniques
summary:
Estimating software development effort is unavoidable in commercial software development. It’s also hard. This talk will help you understand how to develop effective estimation techniques, how they relate to different kinds of projects, how everything and everyone will conspire to make your estimates turn out to be wrong, and how to deal with that. This a practical talk for working programmers, based on real projects, not a theoretical discussion.

Outline:

* Business context - why you make estimates
* Estimation - how you do it
* Verification - identifying bad estimates
* Communication - why estimates are misunderstood
* Improvement - how to make better estimates

Whatever your development methodology, agile or not, you still need good estimates. Meanwhile, methodology discussions and the introduction of new methods both focus on selecting which processes and practices to use on a software development project, and rarely address the details of how you actually implement those practices.

author.speakingReferences: Recent: JavaZone 2011, JFokus 2012, geecon 2012, GOTO Amsterdam 2012. Upcoming (accepted talks): JAX London 2012, Øredev 2012 (invited speaker), TopConf 2012 (invited speaker).
author.speakerBio:
Senior solution architect and Operations Director, having joined Lunatech Research in 2004. Peter works on web application architecture, design and construction, with technical project management. He also does sales, marketing and recruitment work. His interests include Java web application frameworks, agile software development process and practices, and web-based collaboration.

Since 2010, Peter has been a committer on the Play framework open-source project.

Peter is currently writing a ‘Play 2 for Scala’ book, with co-authors Erik Bakker and Francisco Canedo.
author.name: Peter Hilton

wikiPageName: Software project estimation techniques
wikiTitle: Software project estimation techniques
smallTitle: Software project estimation techniques by Peter Hilton

title: How to write functional requirements
summary:
A hard task for any programmer is deciding what to build, which is why software development methodology addresses requirements specification. These days, you could be forgiven for thinking that everyone, or at least everyone else, uses Scrum and just writes user stories on sticky notes. The reality is more complex, and in practice the industry uses many different techniques and levels of documentation, varying from none at all to detailed written specifications. 

This talk covers a range of functional design styles and practical techniques, as well as the fundamental question: doesn’t being ‘agile’ mean that we don’t need written requirements?

* What a functional design is
* What it contains: what to write
* How to write it: gathering information
* Documentation techniques: user stories to detailed specifications
* Diagram techniques: models to mock-ups
* Tools: word processors & wikis

This a practical talk for working programmers, based on real projects, not a theoretical discussion.
wikiPageName: How to write functional requirements
wikiTitle: How to write functional requirements
smallTitle: How to write functional requirements by Peter Hilton

title: The myth of the on-site customer
summary:
Although agile software development methods advocate putting the customer (e.g. Scrum product owner) in the same room as the development team for the duration of the project, this is isn’t usually remotely realistic. This presentation describes four real-world case studies of customers who weren’t ‘in the room’, how this compromised agile software development, how we communicated with the customer instead, and why agile software development techniques still had something to offer.

Case studies:

# The customer who had already written a functional specification
# The customer who we didn’t see for the whole project
# The customer who didn’t know that the team was using Scrum
# The customer who emigrated to Australia during the project
wikiPageName: The myth of the on-site customer
wikiTitle: The myth of the on-site customer
smallTitle: The myth of the on-site customer by Peter Hilton

title: OSGi for the Earthlings: Meet Eclipse Libra!
summary:
This session had been presented on EclipseCon 2010, JavaOne 2011, EclipseCon 2012, JavaOne 2012  and will be updated for the new functionality prior to Javaone and Devoxx. The talk offers a wide variety of live demos showing the capabilities of the tool set. 

Libra is an open source project under the Eclipse Web Tools Platform Container Project. It provides standard tools for OSGi Enterprise application development and in particular tools that integrate the existing WTP and PDE tooling so that OSGi Enterprise applications can be developed with both tooling at the same time. Libra also will enable users to work with tools for better experience in the Server-Side Equinox scenario.

The goals of the project are:

http://www.eclipse.org/libra/

author.speakingReferences:
Android Developer Days 2013: Mobile Java (MGWT), Still Write Once Run Everywhere
JavaOne 2012: OSGi for the earthlings; Meet Eclipse Libra 
JavaOne 2011: OSGi for the earthlings; Meet Eclipse Libra
EclipseCon 2010: Osami Tools for OSGi Developers
Android Developer Days 2012: Mobile Java (MGWT), Still Write Once Run Everywhere (iOS, Android, Bbberry)
Android Developer Days 2012: Android B̶e̶s̶t̶(My)Practises 
Eclipsist 2009&2008: Rich Internet Applications Roundup (JavaFx vs Flex vs Silverlight)
author.speakerBio:
Murat Yener, completed his Bs and Ms degree at Istanbul Technical University. Took part in several projects still in use in ITU Informatics Institute. Worked in Isbank's Core Banking exchange project as J2EE developer. Designed and completed several projects still on market by Muse Systems. Worked in TAV Airports Information Technologies as Enterprise Java & Flex developer. Worked in HSBC as Project Leader responsible for Business Processes and Rich client user interfaces. Currently employed at eteration A.S. working on several projects including  Eclipse Libra Tools, GWT and Mobile applications (both on Android and iOS).
He is also running Google Technology User Group Istanbul since 2009.

Presented several talks at conferences like JavaOne 2011, EclipseCon 2010, EclipseIst 2008/09, Android Developer Days 2012, and several Gtug meetings..
author.name: Murat Yener

wikiPageName: OSGi for the Earthlings  Meet Eclipse Libra!
wikiTitle: OSGi for the Earthlings  Meet Eclipse Libra!
smallTitle: OSGi for the Earthlings: Meet Eclipse Libra! by Murat Yener

title: Software development for smart busy programmers
summary:
Good programmers are smart, busy and want as much time as possible to work on cool stuff and write good code, to they gravitate towards agile software development. However, although agile methods improve on traditional processes, they neither replace the need for basic techniques or teach them. This presentation teaches the essential practical techniques that you need whatever method you are using, agile or not: 

* essential project documentation - telling stakeholders what you’re doing
* functional design - communicating requirements to programmers
* software development estimation - making cost predictions
* essential system documentation - avoiding being on-call for ever.

Writing everything down up-front is easy (but a bad idea): the art of being agile is knowing what you can leave out while still addressing all of a development project’s issues. This session teaches you how.
wikiPageName: Software development for smart busy programmers
wikiTitle: Software development for smart busy programmers
smallTitle: Software development for smart busy programmers by Peter Hilton

title: DevOps Padawan
summary:
As I joined CloudBees as Support Engineer, I discovered an incredible company managing thousand servers and a Cloud platform with a reduced engineering team. I then was introduced to DevOps spirit and tooling, and I discovered a awesome world of power. 

I'm still just a DevOps Padawan, but want to share with you this awesome feeling of getting things done the right way

During this session I'll expose CloudBees internals : how we run Jenkins in the Cloud, how we monitor and manage it, how we provide as many slave you need to build your software, and how the team is organized to improve the platform and do it well. 

May the DevOps be with you
wikiPageName: DevOps Padawan
wikiTitle: DevOps Padawan
smallTitle: DevOps Padawan by Nicolas Loof

title: JavaScript for Java Developers
summary:
Some developers have an impression that JavaScript is a second-league interpreted language with the main purpose of making Web pages a little prettier. But JavaScript is a powerful, flexible, dynamically typed language. JavaScript functions are the first class citizens that can live their own lives. But mastering JavaScript can present a challenge to Java developers who quickly find themselves in the Wild West Land of dynamic programming.

Why you may want to learn JavaScript? 

First, learning how things done in another language makes you a better Java developer. 
Second, HTML5 becomes a new buzzword and adding JavaScript to your skill set make you more valuable software developer. You may not know the best kept secret – any HTML5 project is about learning some new tags, APIs and CSS,but mainly it’s about writing JavaScript code.

The goal of this presentation is to introduce you to this interesting language highlighting the differences with the Java way of doing stuff.

author.speakingReferences: JavaOne, Adobe MAX, multiple presentation at JUGs
author.speakerBio: Yakov Fain works for Farata Systems, a company that provides consulting services in the field of development of enterprise Web applications. He authored several technical books. Sun Microsystems has nominated and awarded Mr. Fain with the title of Java Champion. His latest book "Java Programming. 24-Hour Trainer" was published by Wiley in 2011. Yakov leads the Princeton Java Users Group.
author.name: Yakov Fain

wikiPageName: JavaScript for Java Developers
wikiTitle: JavaScript for Java Developers
smallTitle: JavaScript for Java Developers by Yakov Fain

title: Parallelism in the JVM, from scratch to ForkJoin
summary: The tools available in the JVM for writing code that run in parallel have improved over the years. From directly handling threads to abstractions like the executor service and now the ForkJoin framework much has changed. This talk will walk us through the analysis of different parallel versions of a simple algorithm (merge sort) and the related pros and cons.

author.speakingReferences:
"Performance with Hibernate in cluster" presented at the 2009 edition of Just Java in São Paulo, Brazil

"Understanding Classloaders: Difficulties and Solutions" presented at the 2011 edition of Java One Latin America in São Paulo, Brazil

"Understanding Classloaders: Difficulties and Solutions" presented at the 2012 edition of just Java in São Paulo, Brazil
author.speakerBio:
Java developer for 6 years.

Worked on mission critical applications for the financial market.

Currently developping the Jmine Platform (http://www.jmine.com.br).
author.name: Julien Renaut

wikiPageName: Parallelism in the JVM, from scratch to ForkJoin
wikiTitle: Parallelism in the JVM, from scratch to ForkJoin
smallTitle: Parallelism in the JVM, from scratch to ForkJoin by Julien Renaut

title: Understanding Classloaders: Difficulties and Solutions
summary: While it is an essential feature of all programs written in Java - and specially for Java EE applications - not all developers understand how classloaders work and how to diagnose and solve the most common problems that occur during development and deployment. This talks intends to demistify classloaders and shows what are the most common problems and how to diagnose and solve them.
wikiPageName: Understanding Classloaders  Difficulties and Solutions
wikiTitle: Understanding Classloaders  Difficulties and Solutions
smallTitle: Understanding Classloaders: Difficulties and Solutions by Julien Renaut

title: Tale of an AOM-based application
summary: The Adaptive Object Model architecture has been around for a few years now and we've put it to practice in our applications. The added flexibility turns volatile requirements easier to deal with. On the other hand, database migration between versions can be harder requiring new tools. Through this presentation we would like to share our approach to it as well as the resulting benefits and difficulties.
wikiPageName: Tale of an AOM-based application
wikiTitle: Tale of an AOM-based application
smallTitle: Tale of an AOM-based application by Julien Renaut

title: Develop Hybrid Mobile Applications for both iOS and Android Devices with HTML5 and Java
summary: With the rapid advancement of HTML5 support in the mobile operating systems, developers can now leverage HTML5 and JavaScript to build rich, compelling mobile application user interfaces that mimic native applications. However, business logic and data services would typically be coded using JavaScript or native (e.g. Objective-C) code – neither are ideal for most Java developers. In this session, we will discuss a new framework (Oracle Application Development Framework Mobile) that enable developers to declaratively create HTML5-based user interfaces using JavaServer Faces-like components. For business logic and data services, developers can either declaratively define or code in Java to create these service components. The exact same modules and code would run on both iOS and Android devices. Furthermore, the framework integrates PhoneGap to provide strong device integration, which allows Java developers to create powerful mobile application across different device types. Includes demos on iOS and Android.

author.speakingReferences: JavaOne (in various roles), Documentum Momentum, Microsoft TechEd
author.speakerBio: David Folk leads Oracle's ADF Mobile product management team. This team's objective is to create tools and frameworks that bring Oracle Fusion based applications to mobile devices with a focus on reuse and consistency with existing development methodologies. Previously David led the NetBeans engineering organization.
author.name: David Folk

wikiPageName: Develop Hybrid Mobile Applications for both iOS and Android Devices with HTML5 and Java
wikiTitle: Develop Hybrid Mobile Applications for both iOS and Android Devices with HTML5 and Java
smallTitle: Develop Hybrid Mobile Applications for both iOS and Android Devices with HTML5 a... by David Folk

title: Android Custom Components
summary:
Android comes with many built-in components, but some tasks are best accomplished by rolling your own.

We will start from a simple example of enhancing the TextView class, and finish with a complete custom view with its own size measurement, drawing function and custom attributes. We will also discuss the best practices for custom views. What is the different between a custom view and a fragment? How about a compound control? When to use which?

By the end of the session, you will know not only how to create reusable custom components, but when to use them.

author.speakerBio: Chiu-Ki was on the Android server team when the G1 came out. She switched to apps development when she moved to the maps team, building Google Mobile Maps for Android. After a brief stint in Web development at two startups, Chiu-Ki is now back at her Android roots with her own company for mobile development. The first title is "Monkey Write," an app for learning Chinese writing, which recently won Grand Prize in the Samsung Galaxy Note App Challenge.

title: Fluid Android Layouts
summary: Designing for Android can be super complicated due to the multitude of device sizes. But does it have to be that way? In this talk I will show the design process I used while collaborating with a freelance designer to create Monkey Write. The design goal: To produce a single-device design while keeping an eye on elements that need to be fluid.
wikiPageName: Fluid Android Layouts
wikiTitle: Fluid Android Layouts
smallTitle: Fluid Android Layouts by Chiu-ki Chan

title: Building Living Web Applications - An Introduction to HTML5 WebSockets
summary:
Take your desktop and mobile Web apps to the next level with true, real-time connectivity. Learn how to build real-time, multi-user interaction and collaboration into your Web apps using HTML5 and WebSockets. Whether you want your app to be a real-time retail experience or a fast-paced MMO, you’ll learn hands-on skills to turn your mobile apps into live apps, by building peer-to-peer mobile apps, mobile-desktop interaction, and even turning your smartphone into a Nintendo Wii-style remote control.
Be sure to bring your smartphone or other mobile device to participate in this interactive experience.

author.speakingReferences: OreDev, HTML5DevConf, JavaOne, Oracle OpenWorld, ODTUG, SFHTML5 User Group
author.speakerBio:
Peter Moskovits: Peter is a Developer Advocate for Kaazing, a software company enhancing the way business and customers communicate across the Web using the new HTML5 WebSocket standard. Peter works closely with the developer community to architect and deploy the best possible web communication solutions.
Before joining Kaazing, in various product management leadership roles Peter was responsible for Oracle's portal product strategy.
Peter is the co-author of the Oracle WebCenter 11g Handbook and is a frequent speaker at conferences and industry events, such as JavaOne, Oracle OpenWorld, and various user group meetings.
author.name: Peter Moskovits

wikiPageName: Building Living Web Applications - An Introduction to HTML5 WebSockets
wikiTitle: Building Living Web Applications - An Introduction to HTML5 WebSockets
smallTitle: Building Living Web Applications - An Introduction to HTML5 WebSockets by Peter Moskovits

title: Extending the Reach of Messaging to the Web: Building Real Time Web Apps with WebSockets and JMS
summary:
In this hands-on/guided demo session we walk through the steps of building a Rich Internet Application from scratch, leveraging modern HTML5 Web development concepts. You will use enterprise messaging directly in the browser to build highly dynamic, responsive, and scalable Web applications. Come to this session to learn how you can mix and match Java Message Service (JMS), JavaScript, and HTML5 to build incredibly responsive Web applications for desktop and mobile devices.
The presentation uses a browser-based HTML5 editor and a cloud-hosted WebSocket server.
wikiPageName: Extending the Reach of Messaging to the Web  Building Real Time Web Apps with WebSockets and JMS
wikiTitle: Extending the Reach of Messaging to the Web  Building Real Time Web Apps with WebSockets and JMS
smallTitle: Extending the Reach of Messaging to the Web: Building Real Time Web Apps with We... by Peter Moskovits

summary:
This session had been presented on EclipseCon 2010, JavaOne 2011, EclipseCon 2012, JavaOne 2012 and will be updated for the new functionality prior to Javaone and Devoxx. The talk offers a wide variety of live demos showing the capabilities of the tool set. 

Libra is an open source project under the Eclipse Web Tools Platform Container Project. It provides standard tools for OSGi Enterprise application development and in particular tools that integrate the existing WTP and PDE tooling so that OSGi Enterprise applications can be developed with both tooling at the same time. Libra also will enable users to work with tools for better experience in the Server-Side Equinox scenario.

The goals of the project are:

http://www.eclipse.org/libra/

title: Asynchronous processing in Java EE 6
summary:
The talk will present the various changes around asynchronous processing in Java EE 6, mainly in Servlet 3.0 and EJB 3.1. I'd say these changes are one of the most useful ones in Java EE 6 and it's hard to believe so few people use or are aware of them. The presentation's aim is to change it!
It's assumed to run a demo to show the topic live on stage.

author.speakingReferences: GeeCON, Confitura, warsjawa, devcrowd, JAOO, 4developers, JDD, et al.
author.speakerBio:
Jacek Laskowski has been into Java Enterprise Edition (Java EE) specification and its ecosystem for many years and will surely be spending some more to come. He’s a member of the Apache Software Foundation, and a Project Management Committee (PMC) and a committer of Apache OpenEJB as well as Apache Geronimo open source projects. He’s recently been very interested in functional languages and the decision to study a few ones – Clojure, F#, JRuby and Scala – shapes his current self-learning activities. He also keeps on eye on current developments in Android and OSGi technology areas. He’s the founder and a co-leader of the Warszawa Java User Group (Warszawa JUG) that runs the Confitura and warsjawa conferences in Warsaw, Poland. He’s a book reviewer of IT books, mostly about Java EE, but you may check it out yourself whether or not that still holds true.
He is a Certified IT Specialist (Level 2) for IBM WebSphere in IBM Poland, so you might find a pinch of a bias towards IBM WebSphere stuff here and there. No marketing will however come in.
author.name: Jacek Laskowski

wikiPageName: Asynchronous processing in Java EE 6
wikiTitle: Asynchronous processing in Java EE 6
smallTitle: Asynchronous processing in Java EE 6 by Jacek Laskowski

title: Concurrent programming on JVM? Sure, but only with Clojure!
summary: The goal of the talk is to present the available concurrent abstractions in Clojure and demonstrate their features live on stage. If you've ever considered concurrent programming in Java, you know it's hard to do it right. With Clojure it's much easier and hence it's often referred to as "a small library for concurrent programming".
wikiPageName: Concurrent programming on JVM  Sure, but only with Clojure!
wikiTitle: Concurrent programming on JVM  Sure, but only with Clojure!
smallTitle: Concurrent programming on JVM? Sure, but only with Clojure! by Jacek Laskowski

title: Mobile Java with GWT, Still "Write Once Run Everywhere"
summary:
Once JavaME had ruled the mobile world. Times have changed and JavaME is not really preferred on any modern device today. Android rise pretty fast thanks to large developer community of Java.
However in real world Android is not alone! Many mobile devices running iOS and Blackberry are also exist in mobile universe. 
HTML5+phonegap apps promised a magic silverbullet for write once run on all devices approach via several frameworks which in the end offered painful javascript and css development. While GWT offers a great Java to JS compiler and debugger, MGWT introduces native looking widgets both on ios, android and even blackberry. Also with the addition of gwt-phonegap projects, now you can code native looking html apps which can use native apis only with regular Java without coding a single line of html+JS.
This talk had been highly rated at Android Dev Days Istanbul and Ankara also still waiting for approval to be on JavaOne 2012.
wikiPageName: Mobile Java with GWT, Still Write Once Run Everywhere
wikiTitle: Mobile Java with GWT, Still Write Once Run Everywhere
smallTitle: Mobile Java with GWT, Still "Write Once Run Everywhere" by Murat Yener

title: Android Tips & Tricks
summary:
A non traditional topics to be discussed for beginners about Android, headlines:

1) How to start in Android | Break the ice.
2) You are a Java developer, then you are an Android developer | By default.
3) Stuff you used to do in Java, do them in Android | But easier way.
4) Tricks in Android platform | You might not know.
5) Get your App exposed | Google Play.

author.speakingReferences:
I give an Android course at the information technology institute in Cairo (ITI).
I also give another course about building Android from source (AOSP development).
author.speakerBio:
Software Development Manager @ 3D|Diagnostix.
Graduated from  Computer Science - Cairo University.
The founder & Leader of GDG Cairo (formerly Cairo GTUG).
10 years experience in Programming overall, I write in almost all the programming languages, including Assembly and Prolog.
author.name: Amahdy Abdelaziz

wikiPageName: Android Tips & Tricks
wikiTitle: Android Tips & Tricks
smallTitle: Android Tips & Tricks by Amahdy Abdelaziz

title: Progressive Enhancement for Mobile Web Performance
summary: High performance is of critical importance for the success of any web site, particularly when catering for a wide range of device capabilities and network latencies.  However, before considering performance the site must work reliably across all required devices.  In recent years many of the approaches adopted to achieve high performance rely on the excessive use of JavaScript or techniques supported by only a limited set of devices.  These approaches lead to reduced reliability and support across different devices and higher testing and maintenance costs.  This talk will describe multiple techniques used to progressively enhance performance for web sites without reducing device support.

author.speakingReferences:
Speaker at Future of Mobile - London 2012
Organiser and Speaker at Mobile Web Meetup
Regular Speaker at Betfair
author.speakerBio: James Bloom is the technical lead of mobile web team at Betfair. He has 13 years experience developing web based distributed enterprise systems in a wide range of industries. In his current role, he has focused on building high performance mobile web sites that are designed to run reliably across a wide range of devices with sophisticated progressive enhancement. He has also focused on high quality sustainable delivery through fast feedback loops in agile, continuous delivery, and a very high level of automated testing across a wide range of devices.
author.name: James Bloom

wikiPageName: Progressive Enhancement for Mobile Web Performance
wikiTitle: Progressive Enhancement for Mobile Web Performance
smallTitle: Progressive Enhancement for Mobile Web Performance by James Bloom

title: Mobile Web Best Practices & How We Did It At Betfair
summary: The key to a successful mobile site is high performance and reliability across a wide range of device capabilities and network latencies.  However, the mobile web is a hostile environment with support for HTML5, JavaScript and CSS varying widely across browsers and devices.  This talk will explain best practices to build high performance mobile sites that work across a wide range of devices and capabilities.  The focus will be on lessons learnt at Betfair while rewriting the entire mobile web stack and how we used techniques to maximise performance and reliability.  After discussing the problems faced in mobile the talk will explain how adaptive techniques can be used to provide progressive enhancement.  This will be followed by an explanation of why and where performance bottlenecks occur and how these can be solved.
wikiPageName: Mobile Web Best Practices & How We Did It At Betfair
wikiTitle: Mobile Web Best Practices & How We Did It At Betfair
smallTitle: Mobile Web Best Practices & How We Did It At Betfair by James Bloom

title: JavaFX and Scala in the Cloud
summary:
What do you get when you combine JavaFX and Scala together on top of a Cloud architecture? The most highly scalable platform for Java client development, leveraging the UI richness of JavaFX, elegance of Scala, and scalability of a multi-cloud platform.

We will demonstrate a 100% open-source cloud application built on the jclouds platform using a JavaFX front-end written in Scala. This is an ideal platform for cost-efficient cloud use, since JavaFX lets your client's processor and GPU do the heavy-lifting while you access a lightweight set of REST APIs in the cloud.

We will discuss multi-cloud deployment, writing effective REST services, and building rich user interfaces on top of the common foundation on the Java platform, so you can easily write end-to-end applications leveraging your existing development knowledge and platform. 

By the end of the session you will have learned to build an end-to-end client cloud application from the ground up!
wikiPageName: JavaFX and Scala in the Cloud
wikiTitle: JavaFX and Scala in the Cloud
smallTitle: JavaFX and Scala in the Cloud by Andrew Phillips

title: Hacking the Java compiler for fun and profit
summary:
For Java developers who want to work with the language and platform they love, the last two years have proven to be ground-breaking ones. Java SE 7 was released after a long five-year and brought many new features to make a Java programmer’s life simpler. Such features include reduced generics syntax, safe file handling, making large numbers etc. 

However, wouldn’t it be fun to be able to add your own favourite features to Java?

In this tutorial, we give an introduction to hacking the Java compiler by showing you how to implement a relatively simple new language syntax feature: the Elvis operator.

You will learn:
- how to download and build the Java compiler source code
- how a compiler works and an overview of the Java compiler architecture
- how to modify the Java syntax and grammar
- how to implement the Elvis operator as a feature of Java
- how to test your implementation

author.speakingReferences:

author.speakerBio: Raoul started his PhD in Computer Science at the University of Cambridge at the age of 20. He is a frequent speaker at developer conferences. He holds a MEng in Computer Science from Imperial College London and graduated with first class honours having won several prizes for technical innovation. He has worked on several startup projects as well as worked for large companies such as eBay, Oracle, and Goldman Sachs.

title: ThymeLeaf, a natural HTML 5 templating system for Spring MVC (and other frameworks too)
summary:
Wanna give a second birth to your old Spring MVC web app ?
Wanna switch to HTML 5 without headache ?
Tired of JSP tag soup and bloated logic ?

 Then try ThymeLeaf, the natural HTML 5 templating engine.
 Featuring:
  - natural HTML 5 attribute-base templating
  - WYSIWIG, what you see in static browser rendering is what you'll get at runtime!
  - seemless integration with Spring MVC 3 via dialect system
  - full support of Spring EL for even more powerfull features
  - tons of helper functions for maximum productivity (don't re-invent the wheel!)
  - templates re-use with inclusion & import system
  - scripts support (Javascript & Dart) with inlining system for variable propagation
  - simple integration with Spring Security (no extra taglib)
 
 We'll explore the power and features of ThymeLeaf through a simple REST demo web app

author.speakingReferences:
Technical blog : http://doanduyhai.wordpress.com

 Follow me on Twitter: @doanduyhai
author.speakerBio:
Duy Hai DOAN

 Full stack (from web to OS) Java developer. I am working at SGCIB (Societe General Corporate Investment Banking) as Offshore Technical Leader. Through my daily job I am facing many challenging issues and try to solve them with latest new technologies.
author.name: Duyhai Doan
